Should it be called an operator? It‚Äôs not like it evaluates into an expression by itself‚Äîit‚Äôs kind of more like spread syntax, right?
‚ÄúInterpolation syntax‚Äù, maybe‚Ä¶

Should it be called an operator? It‚Äôs not like it evaluates into an expression by itself‚Äîit‚Äôs kind of more like spread syntax, right?

content.body: I‚Äôm just thinking about that sentence on the MDN chart of operators that says, ‚ÄúThe spread operator is not in this list because it is not an operator,‚Äù and wondering if inconsistently saying ‚Äúinterpolation operator‚Äù might confuse learners.
Interpolation whatever-we-call-it wouldn‚Äôt belong on this operator chart, either.
(I do like and appreciate the word ‚Äúinterpolation‚Äù much more than ‚Äúpin‚Äù, for what it‚Äôs worth.)
"the spread operator is not an operator" seems like a dubious statement
like, it may be true according to some strict technical definition, but I'm not sure it's true by anyone's *pragmatic* definition
content.formatted_body: like, it may be true according to some strict technical definition, but I'm not sure it's true by anyone's pragmatic definition

content.body: spread is definitely not an operator, because it doesn‚Äôt work anywhere in expression position
content.formatted_body: spread is definitely not an operator, because it doesn‚Äôt work anywhere in expression position

content.body: similarly yes, I‚Äôd call the ${} ‚Äúplaceholder syntax‚Äù (cc TabAtkins)
